chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Managing someone with suspected epilepsy
chapter.summary: Covers the management of a person with suspected epilepsy.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage someone with suspected epilepsy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Urgently refer all people suspected of having a first epileptic seizure to a specialist with training and expertise in epilepsy, to confirm the diagnosis.
    • The referral letter should include a detailed description of the seizure from a first-hand witness (if available).
  • Advise the family or carers of the person with suspected epilepsy:
    • How to recognize and manage a seizure. 
      • A factsheet for doctors to give after a first tonic-clonic (grand mal) seizure, including advice on first aid for tonic-clonic seizures and when to call an ambulance is available from Epilepsy Action (www.epilepsy.org.uk).
    • To record any further episodes of possible seizures, for example using a video available on a mobile phone (ensure informed consent is obtained before recording) or seizure diary.
  • Advise the person with suspected epilepsy (or their family or carers if appropriate): 
    • That the term epilepsy is used to describe a condition in which people have a tendency to have seizures, but there are other possible causes for seizures.
    • To stop driving while waiting to see the specialist for confirmation of the diagnosis, to avoid potentially dangerous work or leisure activities (for example working with heavy machinery or at heights, or swimming), and to be mindful of safety in the home (for example showering rather than taking baths), and at school.
      • Written safety advice for people with seizures and information on driving and epilepsy is available from Epilepsy Action (www.epilepsy.org.uk).
    • About lifestyle factors that may lower the seizure threshold and make recurrence more likely, for example sleep deprivation and the use of alcohol and social drugs.
    • To take a witness of the seizure to the first hospital appointment, if possible.
    • To contact their GP if further episodes occur while they are waiting to see the specialist — seek urgent specialist advice if there is concern about recurrent episodes of suspected seizures. 
  • Advise about available sources of information and support for people with epilepsy and their family and/or carers.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Urgent referral for all people with a first seizure
  • The recommendation to refer people urgently for specialist confirmation of the diagnosis of epilepsy is largely based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) guideline The Epilepsies. The diagnosis and management of the epilepsies in adults and children in primary and secondary care [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012b]. The NICE Guideline Development Group considered that for a recent-onset suspected seizure, referrals should be urgent meaning the person should be seen within two weeks.
    • The NICE guideline states that misdiagnosis of epilepsy occurs in around 25% of cases [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012b]. 
  • Specialist referral is also recommended in the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guidelines Diagnosis and management of epilepsy in adults [SIGN, 2018].
    • The SIGN guideline for adults states that a significant proportion of epilepsy diagnoses made by non-specialists is incorrect, and epilepsy may be difficult to diagnose in the early stages [SIGN, 2018].  
  • It is important that identification of the seizure type and epilepsy syndrome is attempted, and a distinction made between genetic generalised epilepsies and focal epilepsies as this can have management and prognostic implications [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012b; SIGN, 2018]. Investigations which may be arranged by the specialist include:
    • Neuroimaging — MRI scanning is the standard imaging tool to identify lesions such as small tumours, vascular malformations, and cortical dysplasia that are not detected by CT [Krishnamurthy, 2016; SIGN, 2018; Thijs et al, 2019].  
    • Electroencephalography (EEG) — helpful in determining the likely seizure type and the likely risk of seizure recurrence [Gavvala and Schuele, 2016; Thijs et al, 2019], although it cannot exclude a diagnosis of epilepsy [SIGN, 2018]. 
Advice to family or carers
  • Advising the family or carers on how to recognize and manage a seizure is extrapolated from a checklist of information patients and carers may find helpful in the SIGN guideline Diagnosis and management of epilepsy in adults that highlights the importance of advising on general first aid guidelines and when to call an ambulance [SIGN, 2018].
    • The risk of a subsequent seizure is at its greatest shortly after the first seizure, with 60–70% of seizure recurrences occurring within the first 6 months [Legg and Newton, 2017, Counselling adults who experience a first seizure].  
  • The recommendation to record any further episodes of possible seizures is based on expert opinion in the NICE guideline The Epilepsies. The diagnosis and management of the epilepsies in adults and children in primary and secondary care [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012b], and the SIGN guideline Diagnosis and management of epilepsy in adults [SIGN, 2018]. 
    • The NICE guideline states that 'prospective recording of events, including video recording and written descriptions, can be very helpful in reaching a diagnosis' [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012b]. 
    • The SIGN guideline states that asking family or friends to videorecord events should be considered in a person with an uncertain diagnosis as epileptic seizures can be distinguished from non-epileptic seizures by analysing the behaviours observed [SIGN, 2018]. 
Advice to the person with suspected epilepsy
  • Expert opinion in a review article on counselling adults who experience a first seizure proposes discussing the distinction between a first seizure and a diagnosis of epilepsy and providing information about other possible causes of seizure [Legg and Newton, 2017, Counselling adults who experience a first seizure]. 
  • The recommendations regarding preliminary advice about stopping driving, are based on the SIGN guideline Diagnosis and management of epilepsy in adults which advises that people referred following a suspected first seizure should not drive until they have seen an epilepsy specialist. This guideline also suggests taking an eyewitness (or eyewitness contact details) to the appointment because a clear history from the person and an eyewitness to the attack gives the most important diagnostic information [SIGN, 2018]. 
  • The NICE guideline The Epilepsies. The diagnosis and management of the epilepsies in adults and children in primary and secondary care, recommends giving advice to people with epilepsy and their families and carers on safety and injury prevention at home, school or work [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012b]. Other expert opinions in review articles agrees, stating that a discussion about safety is paramount and that a recurrent seizure could put the person (or others) at risk of injury or death [Gavvala and Schuele, 2016; Legg and Newton, 2017, Counselling adults who experience a first seizure].  
  • The recommendation to contact the person's GP if there are recurrent seizure episodes before specialist assessment is pragmatic based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice. 
Providing information and support
  • The recommendation to provide information and support to people with suspected epilepsy and their family and carers before the diagnosis is confirmed is based on expert opinion in the NICE guideline The Epilepsies. The diagnosis and management of the epilepsies in adults and children in primary and secondary care [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012b].
    • NICE recommends that essential information on how to recognize a seizure, first aid, and the importance of reporting further attacks is provided while the person is awaiting a diagnosis [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012b].  
    • Expert opinion in a review article on counselling adults who experience a first seizure also advises providing a person with written and online materials and community resources [Legg and Newton, 2017, Counselling adults who experience a first seizure].
